executive_summary: The industry includes dry cleaning and full-service laundry establishments that cater to household consumers and commercial clients such as hotels and restaurants. Dry cleaners may also offer specialty cleaning services for delicate garments and textiles. Over the past five years, the industry has experienced difficult operating conditions. Declining demand for professional dry-cleaning services, unfavorable shifts in consumer preferences and increasing competition from coin-operated laundromats, franchised establishments and substitute products have led to the industry's decline. Also, COVID-19 and the economic downturn resulted in drastic revenue declines in 2020. Consequently, industry revenue is expected to fall at a CAGR of 4.9% to $8.3 billion over the past five years, with a rise of 1.1% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: For two decades, dry cleaners have contended with declining demand and increasingly difficult operating conditions. The pandemic has significantly exacerbated these trends since unemployed and financially insecure consumers either had no need for dry cleaning services or could not afford them. Also, work-from-home policies have resulted in an even greater shift to casual attire at the workplace, reducing demand for dry cleaning services. Amid these declines, cleaners have experienced rising operational costs and slim profit. Many have been forced to exit the industry or attempt to cut costs by drastically reducing their workforce.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Dry cleaners struggled over the past five years
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Dry cleaners struggled over the past five years in large part due to a sharp decline in 2020 caused by the pandemic. Most of the industry is composed of independently operated dry cleaning establishments. Because of its classification as a nonessential business, many of these independent businesses were forced out of the industry in 2020 due to the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Traditional brick-and-mortar businesses are expected to fare worse
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Traditional brick-and-mortar businesses are expected to fare worse than some of their counterparts. Dry cleaners with no-contact pick-up and drop-off services, such as locker systems that have become popular with larger dry cleaners, have fared better than brick-and-mortar establishments, as competition shifts to being based on the perceived level of cleanliness and social distancing adherence.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand from the Commercial Market is Expected to Increase
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Dry cleaners will continue targeting commercial markets to hedge against reduced demand from residential customers. The largest commercial clients for full-service laundry are hospitals, restaurants and hotels. The industry provides these commercial clients with pick-up and delivery services for laundering uniforms, towels, sheets, comforters, napkins, tablecloths and other linens.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Regulatory Environment will Continue to be a Hurdle for Dry Cleaners
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, the industry will endure even greater regulatory scrutiny, especially if more states ban both residential and commercial use of perchloroethylene (PCE) and other hazardous solvents. A substantial number of dry cleaners still rely on PCE as their primary solvent, despite the consensus that it is harmful to human health and the environment.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE INDUSTRY'S LANDSCAPE WILL CONTINUE TO GET MORE COMPETITIVE
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Intensifying competition between dry cleaners and other industries will continue to constrict dry cleaners' profit over the next five years, leading to stagnation. Profit will be adversely affected by rebounding utility costs and a spike in the price of hangers and other required purchases, a significant cost for dry cleaners.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: EMPLOYMENT TRENDS WILL DETERMINE HOW DRY CLEANERS RECOVER
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: How current trends influence where employees work and what consumers wear will determine the industry's performance moving forward.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry provide dry cleaning and laundering services. Companies may also provide drop-off and pick-up sites for customers. In addition, establishments may also offer specialty cleaning services for
key_trends: The COVID-19 pandemic decimated the dry cleaning industry. Despite being named an essential service, consumers abandoned dry cleaners in an effort to save money.

Larger dry cleaning operations that service the commercial sector have recovered significantly from the pandemic. Key downstream markets like hotel chains and restaurants have experienced increased volume, requiring more dry cleaning services.

EPA guidelines restricting the use of the toxic chemical perchloroethylene (PCE) have led to the adoption of more ecologically friendly alternatives. While technique and application have remained the same, the waste produced by dry cleaning operations has diminished while the cost of operations has gone up.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households have historically been the largest market for dry cleaners. Demand for professional dry cleaning services is highest among white-collar workers that own professional garments that cannot be washed at home and must be dry cleaned. Households earning $100,000 or more annually account for the highest share of revenue.

Demand from the commercial sector is derived from hospitals, hotels, restaurants, religious congregations and other nonprofit organizations. Hospitals require pick-up and delivery services to launder uniforms, sheets and towels. The healthcare sector has been a particular growth segment for the industry as per capita health expenditure rises. Hotel and motel establishments are another significant area of demand for dry cleaning services.
Households earning less than $50K annually account for a smaller share of revenue compared to higher income households.
Households earning between $50K and $100K annually account for a moderate share of industry revenue.
Nonprofits and other institutional clients such as religious congregations account for a small portion of industry demand.

products_and_services.product_description: Dry cleaning services offered to individual consumers.
Full-service laundry services catered to businesses and commercial clients.

tier_1_suppliers: Soap & Cleaning Compound Manufacturing in the US
Electrical Equipment Wholesaling in the US
TV & Appliance Wholesaling in the US
Plumbing & Heating Supplies Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Plastic Products Miscellaneous Manufacturing in the US
Organic Chemical Manufacturing in the US
Electrical Equipment Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Celebrity & Sports Agents in the US
Movie & Video Distribution in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Retail Dry Cleaning and Laundry Services Continue to Account for the Largest Share of Revenue
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Dry cleaning is a clothing and textile cleaning process that traditionally uses a chemical solvent instead of water. Since the 1930s, the most common solvent used has been perchloroethylene (PCE). However, for more than a decade, PCE has been under fire due to its hazardous effects on the environment and human health.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Commercial Dry Cleaning and Laundry has Increased
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Commercial full-service dry cleaning and laundry includes revenue from laundering and ironing garments, linens and textiles for commercial or institutional clients. Establishments also provide pick-up and drop-off services for laundry and dry cleaning items. Pick-up and drop-off laundering services have experienced high growth and are one of the most profitable service offerings for dry cleaners.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Other Service Offerings Will Continue to Expand
demand_determinants.determinant_description: These services include garment maintenance, repair and tailoring services, steam pressing, ironing and clothing storage. Miscellaneous products and services include garment and laundry equipment rental, in addition to resales of unrelated merchandise.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region holds the highest concentration of dry cleaners in the country. Its dense and relatively affluent population, coupled with its multitude of urban centers, creates a high demand for dry cleaning services. Most revenue in the Mid-Atlantic is generated from the densely populated markets along the Northeast, which includes New York City, Philadelphia and Washington, DC.

The Southeast region has the second-highest concentration of industry establishments and closely mirrors the region's percentage of the country's total population. The region also produces more than one-quarter of industry revenue.

The West is the third-highest center for the industry, though establishments are primarily located in California. The region's concentration of dry-cleaning locations corresponds with its percentage of the population. The West has a higher median income level than the average for the nation. Since consumers with household incomes exceeding $60,000 annually are the industry's primary customers, the region's higher-than-average income level is one of the reasons for the industry's high concentration level.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The EPA began issuing regulations to control perchloroethylene (PCE), which is classified as a hazardous air and water contaminant and a likely carcinogenic.
Dry cleaners are subject to regulations from the Clean Water Act, the Resources Conservation and Recovery Act, and the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Recovery Act.
The industry is subject to provisions relating to airborne pollution emissions under the Clean Air Act.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
The industry has a high level of revenue volatility.
The level of industry assistance is low and increasing.
The level of competition is high and increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: The biggest threat to industry profitability is individuals who opt to do their own dry cleaning.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry has a very low level of market share concentration. Since most enterprises are family-owned companies that employ fewer than five people, the industry remains highly fragmented.

The detrimental effects of COVID-19 and the economic downturn altered the industry's market share concentration. Smaller dry cleaners suffered while larger businesses better equipped to handle the evolving environment are expected to acquire them.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rising cost of materials increases purchase costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include clothing hangers, detergents, bleach, fabric softeners, solvents and garments. The rising cost of materials can be attributed to the soaring inflation endured after the pandemic.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Dry cleaning is a labor-intensive business
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While automation has slowly crept into the industry, the majority of work necessitates human input.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patents and concentration of patents
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Historically stable revenue endures a decline
volatility_points.volatility_description: Prior to 2020, the industry experienced little fluctuation in revenue growth, with the industry contending with a mix of modest declines and sparse gains.

volatility_points.volatility_title: COVID-19 caused times of economic crisis
volatility_points.volatility_description: Much of the volatility experienced during the period was due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its significant effect on the economy in 2020 and 2021.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Retail dry cleaning and laundry services continue to account for largest share of revenue
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Dry cleaners have begun using substitute solvents, such as high-temperature hydrocarbons and silicone-based solvents, in response to increasing regulatory scrutiny.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Demand from commercial dry cleaning and laundry has increased
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Commercial full-service dry cleaning and laundry includes revenue from laundering and ironing garments, linens and textiles for commercial or institutional clients.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Other service offerings will continue to expand
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: These services include garment maintenance, repair and tailoring services, steam pressing, ironing and clothing storage.

FAQs.question: Though marketing costs are generally low for operators, how have you increased exposure while keeping costs manageable?
FAQs.answer: To avoid rising costs, many operators opted for free marketing strategies, such as using social media platforms.

FAQs.question: How does your company fair amid economic downturns?
FAQs.answer: Periods of declining or disrupted economic activity result in significantly detrimental effects on industry revenue. Dry cleaning services are relatively expensive and there are myriad substitute products and services available, which are generally less expensive. As a result, operators experienced significant declines in demand as cash-strapped consumers opted to forgo dry cleaning services or use less expensive substitute products.

FAQs.question: How has your company adjusted pricing strategies amid economic downturns to maintain consumers?
FAQs.answer: Due to the high and rising level of competition, both internally and externally, operators experience difficulty effectively passing rising costs on to customers. As a result, operators with strong brand recognition or consumer loyalty are best equipped to weather economic disruptions.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer ancillary services to supplement revenue during periods of declining demand?
FAQs.answer: Most operators offer a slew of ancillary services, such as sewing and tailoring services. While these services provide another reason for consumers to frequent them, they generally do not come close to fully supplementing revenue during periods of declining demand.

FAQs.question: How has your company leveraged evolving technologies, such as RFID systems, to remain competitive in an increasingly competitive landscape?
FAQs.answer: RFID systems have become integral to industry operations, as establishments hand a high volume of varying articles of clothing and customers. RFID provide an easy way for operators to keep track of their orders and clients, and reduce the need for additional employees, keeping costs from rising exponentially.

FAQs.question: Has your company invested in updating your technologies to align with shifting regulations and make operations safer and more efficient?
FAQs.answer: Most operators have or are in the process of switching out their PCE machines with carbon dioxide and high-temperature hydrocarbons machines. Such technological changes have become integral to keeping costs manageable and staying abreast of evolving regulations.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay abreast of the evolving regulatory environment to ensure the safety of your employees, customers and their clothing?
FAQs.answer: Amid the pandemic, operators have needed to ensure various regulations and policies pertaining to the health and safety of their customers and employees are met. Operators can stay abreast of these changes by frequenting association websites, such as the National Cleaners Association and American Drycleaner.

FAQs.question: How does your company comply and stay abreast of the evolving regulatory landscape in relation to environmental standards for dry cleaning practices?
FAQs.answer: Operators must adhere to a variety of environmentally-related regulations, as chemicals traditionally used in dry cleaning practices have been identified as increasingly harmful to various components of the environment. The EPA provides operators with guidance and instructions on changes in regulations that pertain to their equipment and chemicals used, including the prohibition of new installation of PCE dry-cleaning machines.

FAQs.question: What are the greatest effects of economic downturns on your company's financial performance?
FAQs.answer: Dry cleaners experienced a dire financial situation amid economic downturns, reducing consumers' need for dry cleaning services.

FAQs.question: How do economic downturns affect your company's profit margin?
FAQs.answer: The average dry cleaners profit declines during periods of economic downturns as fewer people will be inclined to use the industry's services.

FAQs.question: How do you manage the high costs associated with updating your dry cleaning technology? How do you ensure your workforce is trained on new technologies?
FAQs.answer: Radio-frequency identification systems (RFID) have become increasingly important for industry operators, as they deal with many pieces of clothing and the systems enable operators to easily sort them and remain organized. Additionally, over the past five years, many operators have replaced their PCE machines with washers that use carbon dioxide or high-temperature hydrocarbons, such as DF2000 or EcoSolve.

FAQs.question: Do you open establishments in close proximity to densely populated areas?
FAQs.answer: Most industry operators open establishments in or near cities and other areas of high population density.

FAQs.question: How has catering to niche markets enabled you to avoid some of the greater disruptions? What niche markets do you traditionally serve?
FAQs.answer: Operators specializing in serving markets relatively unaffected by the pandemic and nonessential business closures, particularly health care markets. However, most operators try to serve a variety of downstream markets rather than focusing on one market, as this enables them to weather periods of declining demand from one market better.

FAQs.question: How has your company managed increased competition?
FAQs.answer: Franchised establishments have become an increasingly prevalent form of external competition for industry operators, as many prior participants in the industry have converted to franchised operations, bringing their brand recognition and experience to a competing industry. Operators experience difficulty offering different services from franchises, along with lower prices, as franchises generally stay abreast of changing consumer preferences and can offer lower prices due to economies of scale.

FAQs.question: Are there any services you offer to specifically compete with external competitors?
FAQs.answer: Franchised establishments have become an increasingly prevalent form of external competition for industry operators, as many prior participants in the industry have converted to franchised operations, bringing their brand recognition and experience to a competing industry. Operators experience difficulty offering different services from franchises, along with lower prices, as franchises generally stay abreast of changing consumer preferences and can offer lower prices due to economies of scale.

FAQs.question: Do you serve a range of downstream customers or focus on one segment?
FAQs.answer: Businesses account for a significant share of industry revenue, proving to be an important aspect of the average dry cleaners' operations. Most operators serve a variety of downstream markets to ensure the ability to remain in demand despite fluctuations in certain markets.

FAQs.question: How do fluctuations in disposable income levels affect demand for your business? Do you offer any deals or discounts during periods of declining disposable income?
FAQs.answer: Increased disposable income is not estimated to benefit the industry as much. As more people work from home, it removes the need for professional dry cleaning services.
